QuestionTxt: Now, please report whether your overall opinion of each of the following is very favorable, mostly favorable, mostly unfavorable, or very unfavorable...Barack Obama
StudyNote: The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national YouthPulse panel. The initial sample drawn from the YouthPulse panel was adjusted using pre-stratification weights so that it approximates the overall population (15 to 24 year olds) in the US defined by the latest Current Population Survey.  Next, a probability proportional to size sampling scheme was used to select a representative sample. Once assigned to the survey, panel participants received an email notification reminder on day four, seven and twelve of the field period. The YouthPulse panel is a nationally representative probability sample of teens and young adults age 15 to 24 years old. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling. Participants under the age of 18 were included in the panel following the receipt of parental consent. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into the panel; and are generally limited to how many surveys they can take within a given time period.

SourceDoc: Pew Research Center's American Trends Panel Poll
SampleDesc: National adult (2066 panelists completed by web and 1778 panelists completed by phone)
IntMethod: Telephone Interview, Cell Phone; Telephone Interview, Landline; Computer-Assisted telephone interview (CATI); Web-based survey
StudyNote:
2066 respondents were interviewed online and 1778 by telephone. 
The American Trends Panel (ATP), created by the Pew Research Center, is a nationally representative panel of randomly selected US adults living in households. Respondents who self-identify as Internet users (representing 89% of US adults) participate in the panel via monthly self-administered Web surveys, and those who do not use the Internet participate via telephone or mail. The panel is being managed by Abt SRBI. Question wording in this topline is that from the web version of the survey. Question wording and format was adapted for the paper questionnaire delivered by mail.

SurveyOrg: The Associated Press-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research
StudyNote:
846 respondents were interviewed online, and 171 by telephone. 
Interviews were conducted both online using a self-administered design and by telephone using live interviewers. All interviews were conducted among participants in AmeriSpeak, a probability-based panel designed to be representative of the national US adult population run by NORC at the University of Chicago. Panel participants without Internet access were interviewed via telephone by professional interviewers under the direction of NORC. NORC's AmeriSpeak Panel provides a representative panel of civilian, non-institutional adults (age 18 and over) living in the United States.
	45% of completed interviews are sourced from Amerispeak, and 55% of completed interviews are sourced from a panel of young adults custom built by NORC. The Young Adult sample is from a probability-based household panel that uses an address based sample from a registered voter database of the entire US. Households were selected using stratified random sampling to support over-sampling of households with African Americans, Hispanics, and Asians ages 18-30. NORC contacted sampled households by US mail and by telephone, inviting them to register and participate in public opinion surveys twice a month

We'll show the name of a person or group and we'd like you to rate that person or group using something we call the feeling thermometer. Ratings between 50 degrees and 100 degrees mean that you feel favorable and warm toward the person. Ratings between 0 degrees and 50 degrees mean that you don't feel favorable toward the person and you don't care too much for that person. You would rate the person at the 50 degree mark if you don't feel particularly warm or cold toward the person.)...Barack Obama
QuestionNote: This question was asked as part of an experiment to investigate whether media accounts contribute to the persistence of biological racism among White Americans. The total 2,034 White, non-Hispanic adult respondents were assigned randomly to two treatment groups (race as genetics condition or race as social construction condition) or a control. Respondents were then asked questions intended to measure feelings regarding whether biological racial differences exist, three strikes legislation, the death penalty, and racial resentment. This allowed for deeper understanding of whether ostensibly innocuous messages about race, health, and genetics have consequences on public attitudes towards race.
SubPopulation: Asked of control group, respondents who read no fictitious news articles about racial disparities in heart disease (n=661)
SampleDesc: National White, non-Hispanic adults who completed the Public Affairs profile survey
StudyNote:
Weighted results shown. Individual-level unweighted data with weight variable available for download 
for further analyses. Full treatment information available in Downloads.

SurveyOrg: Anderson Robbins Research; Shaw & Co. Research
StudyNote: 656 respondents were interviewed on a landline telephone, and 350 were interviewed on a cell phone. Interviews were conducted by Braun Research.

QuestionTxt: I'd like to get your feelings toward some of our political leaders and other people who have been in the news. I'll read the name of a person and I'd like you to rate that person using something called the feeling thermometer. You can choose any number between 0 and 100. The higher the number, the warmer or more favorable you feel toward that person, the lower the number, the colder or less favorable. If we come to a person who you haven't heard enough about to form an opinion, you don't need to rate the person. Just tell me and we'll move on to the next one....How do you feel about...Barack Obama?
StudyNote: The interviews included landline and cell phones.

QuestionTxt: For each of the following individuals, please select if you have a favorable or unfavorable impression of that person. If you don't know enough about the person to have an opinion, you can say that too....Very favorable, somewhat favorable, somewhat unfavorable, very unfavorable, don't know enough to say...Barack Obama
StudyNote: The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel.  The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the U.S. adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 U.S. households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the U.S. adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week.

QuestionTxt: Please rate your feelings towards Barack Obama. Is your overall impression of him extremely favorable, favorable, somewhat favorable, neither favorable nor favorable, somewhat unfavorable, unfavorable, extremely unfavorable
QuestionNote: This question was asked as part of an experiment to test whether increased conservatism in response to the growth of an outgroup, as previously observed in non-Hispanic White populations, is also observed in racial minority groups. A total of 620 respondents participated. Respondents were randomly assigned to read one of two press releases from the U.S. Census Bureau describing either the growth of non-White populations in the U.S. or the growth in geographic mobility. All respondents were surveyed on their concerns about the current state of the societal system/American culture, feelings toward non-Hispanic Whites, Asians, Hispanics, and Blacks, policy preferences related to immigration and national defense, and political ideology. This allowed for comparison of White and racial minority subgroup reactions to the growth of a minority outgroup.
SubPopulation: Asked of control group, respondents who read a US Census press release on the increase in geographic mobility (n=317)
SurveySponsor: Craig, Maureen and Jennifer A. Richeson
SampleDesc: National adults who completed the Public Affairs profile survey
StudyNote: Weighted results shown. Individual-level unweighted data with weight variable available for download for further analyses. Full treatment information available in Downloads.

QuestionTxt: Next, I'd like you to rate Barack Obama on a scale.  If you have a favorable opinion of him, name a number between plus one and plus five--where a plus five is the highest position indicating you have a very favorable opinion of him.  If you have an unfavorable opinion, name a number between minus one and minus five where minus five is the lowest position--indicating you have a very unfavorable opinion of him.  How far up or down the scale would you rate Barack Obama?
SampleDesc: National adult including an oversample of African Americans
IntMethod: Telephone Interview, Cell Phone; Telephone Interview, Landline

The oversample of 376 non-Hispanic blacks consisted of 88 interviews done as part of the random national sample, and 288 interviews with blacks who had previously participated in national Gallup Polls, and agreed to be re-interviewed at a later date.   Results were weighted to be representative of a national adult population.

QuestionTxt: Okay, to get started I'd like to get your feelings toward some of the groups and people in American society.  I'll read the name of a group or person and I'd like you to rate that group or person using something we call the feeling thermometer.  Ratings between 50 degrees and 100 degrees mean that you feel favorable and warm toward the group or person.  Ratings between 0 and 50 degrees mean that you have unfavorable feelings toward the group or person and that you don't care too much for them.  You would rate the group or person at 50 if you don't feel particularly warm or cold toward them.  If we come to a group whose name you don't recognize, you don't need to rate that group.  Just tell me and we'll move on to the next one....President (Barack) Obama
SourceDoc: National Hispanic Media Coalition/Latino Decisions The Impact of Media Stereotypes on Opinions and Attitudes Toward Latinos Survey
StudyNote: There was also an online survey of 3000 non-Latino adults who responded to questions about Latinos and immigrants after watching video clips, reading articles, or listening to audio clips about them.

QuestionTxt: Please rate your feelings towards Barack Obama. Is your overall impression of him extremely favorable, favorable, somewhat favorable, neither favorable nor favorable, somewhat unfavorable, unfavorable, extremely unfavorable
QuestionNote: This question was asked as part of an experiment to test whether increased conservatism in response to the growth of an outgroup, as previously observed in non-Hispanic White populations, is also observed in racial minority groups. A total of 620 respondents participated. Respondents were randomly assigned to read one of two press releases from the U.S. Census Bureau describing either the growth of non-White populations in the U.S. or the growth in geographic mobility. All respondents were surveyed on their concerns about the current state of the societal system/American culture, feelings toward non-Hispanic Whites, Asians, Hispanics, and Blacks, policy preferences related to immigration and national defense, and political ideology. This allowed for comparison of White and racial minority subgroup reactions to the growth of a minority outgroup.
SubPopulation: Asked of treatment group, respondents who read a US Census press release on the growth of minority populations (n=303)
SurveySponsor: Craig, Maureen and Jennifer A. Richeson
SampleDesc: National adults who completed the Public Affairs profile survey
StudyNote: Weighted results shown. Individual-level unweighted data with weight variable available for download for further analyses. Full treatment information available in Downloads.

QuestionTxt: Weâd like you to rate Barack Obama using something we call the feeling thermometer. Ratings between 50 and 100 degrees mean that you feel favorably and warm toward Obama; ratings between 0 and 50 degrees mean that you donât feel favorably toward Obama and that you don't care too much for him. You would rate him at the 50 degree mark if you donât feel particularly warm or cold toward Obama. How do you rate Barack Obama on this thermometer?
QuestionNote: This question was asked as part of an experiment to test whether a frame that makes a consideration accessible by denying its applicability generates a framing effect. Three experimental conditions and one control condition were included in each condition for a total of 2,365 respondents. In each of the three experimental conditions, respondents were presented with different framings of where blame lies in the economic conditions of the day (uncertain, President is responsible, President is not responsible) and then asked whether they believe that President Barack Obama is responsible. Control condition respondents were not presented with information on current economic conditions and were not asked to answer the attribution question. All respondents were asked to evaluate President Obamaâs overall job performance and his handling of foreign, economic, healthcare, education, and energy policy. This allowed for comparison of how accessibility of considerations affect an individualâs evaluation of presidential job performance.
SubPopulation: Asked of treatment group 3, respondents who were told that the President was not responsible for current economic conditions (n=590)
SampleDesc: National adults who completed the Public Affairs profile survey
StudyNote:
Weighted results shown. Individual-level unweighted data with weight variable available for download 
for further analyses. Full treatment information available in Downloads.

QuestionTxt: Please rate your feelings towards Barack Obama. Is your overall impression of him...favorable, somewhat favorable, neither favorable nor unfavorable, somewhat unfavorable, or unfavorable?
QuestionNote: This question was asked as part of an experiment to test whether a frame that makes a consideration accessible by denying its applicability generates a framing effect. Three experimental conditions and one control condition were included in each condition for a total of 2,365 respondents. In each of the three experimental conditions, respondents were presented with different framings of where blame lies in the economic conditions of the day (uncertain, President is responsible, President is not responsible) and then asked whether they believe that President Barack Obama is responsible. Control condition respondents were not presented with information on current economic conditions and were not asked to answer the attribution question. All respondents were asked to evaluate President Obamaâs overall job performance and his handling of foreign, economic, healthcare, education, and energy policy. This allowed for comparison of how accessibility of considerations affect an individualâs evaluation of presidential job performance.
SubPopulation: Asked of control group, respondents presented with no information on current economic conditions (n=619)
SampleDesc: National adults who completed the Public Affairs profile survey
StudyNote:
Weighted results shown. Individual-level unweighted data with weight variable available for download 
for further analyses. Full treatment information available in Downloads.

QuestionTxt: Weâd like you to rate Barack Obama using something we call the feeling thermometer. Ratings between 50 and 100 degrees mean that you feel favorably and warm toward Obama; ratings between 0 and 50 degrees mean that you donât feel favorably toward Obama and that you don't care too much for him. You would rate him at the 50 degree mark if you donât feel particularly warm or cold toward Obama. How do you rate Barack Obama on this thermometer?
QuestionNote: This question was asked as part of an experiment to test whether a frame that makes a consideration accessible by denying its applicability generates a framing effect. Three experimental conditions and one control condition were included in each condition for a total of 2,365 respondents. In each of the three experimental conditions, respondents were presented with different framings of where blame lies in the economic conditions of the day (uncertain, President is responsible, President is not responsible) and then asked whether they believe that President Barack Obama is responsible. Control condition respondents were not presented with information on current economic conditions and were not asked to answer the attribution question. All respondents were asked to evaluate President Obamaâs overall job performance and his handling of foreign, economic, healthcare, education, and energy policy. This allowed for comparison of how accessibility of considerations affect an individualâs evaluation of presidential job performance.
SubPopulation: Asked of control group, respondents presented with no information on current economic conditions (n=619)
SampleDesc: National adults who completed the Public Affairs profile survey
StudyNote:

QuestionTxt: Weâd like you to rate Barack Obama using something we call the feeling thermometer. Ratings between 50 and 100 degrees mean that you feel favorably and warm toward Obama; ratings between 0 and 50 degrees mean that you donât feel favorably toward Obama and that you don't care too much for him. You would rate him at the 50 degree mark if you donât feel particularly warm or cold toward Obama. How do you rate Barack Obama on this thermometer?
QuestionNote: This question was asked as part of an experiment to test whether a frame that makes a consideration accessible by denying its applicability generates a framing effect. Three experimental conditions and one control condition were included in each condition for a total of 2,365 respondents. In each of the three experimental conditions, respondents were presented with different framings of where blame lies in the economic conditions of the day (uncertain, President is responsible, President is not responsible) and then asked whether they believe that President Barack Obama is responsible. Control condition respondents were not presented with information on current economic conditions and were not asked to answer the attribution question. All respondents were asked to evaluate President Obamaâs overall job performance and his handling of foreign, economic, healthcare, education, and energy policy. This allowed for comparison of how accessibility of considerations affect an individualâs evaluation of presidential job performance.
SubPopulation: Asked of treatment group 2, respondents who were told that the President was responsible for current economic conditions (n=580)
SampleDesc: National adults who completed the Public Affairs profile survey
StudyNote:

for further analyses. Full treatment information available in Downloads.
